blog.name: ineffableplan
blog.title: That Hieronymus Bosch. What a weirdo.
blog.description: A Good Omens side-blog. | Mostly running on the queue. | Ask to tag | I tag for #lemon, so you may block it | About Discord server invites for mobile | I'm usually known as Socks, they/them, 20-something, just here for the laughs | Posts are okay to add to and I like hearing other people's headcanons and opinions, they're fun

tags: i wrote this abnormally fast because people on a discord server gave me emotions
summary: fic, also on ao3 Crowley, after a short time—short even by the reckoning of humans—begins to steal Aziraphale’s sweaters....
body:
fic, also on ao3

Crowley, after a short time—short even by the reckoning of humans—begins to steal Aziraphale’s sweaters.

They’re warm and soft, threads running in places and the seams are fraying on the inside but they’re good; they’re better than great. They’re real, not just through coming into existence by organic, human means, handmade and hand-sold and angel-bought, so different from Crowley’s millennia of manifested designs, but from being loved and lived in and cared for. There’s something solid to them, a presence Crowley hadn’t known he was missing, or had deliberately forgotten somewhere in a far-flung effort to pretend at being something he couldn’t have.

They hang off his frame like he’s wearing a tent; the sleeves slip and drag in the dishwater when he scrubs at a plate, Aziraphale waiting patiently beside him with a dishtowel and a smile that makes something in Crowley’s chest bloom like blossoms in spring if he’s brave enough to risk a glance.

He wanders the cottage, drowning in washed-out dyes and decades loved wool, tucks himself under his angel’s arm at the end of a dreamy day and wraps his fingers graciously around a mug of cocoa that always has just a touch too much cinnamon but the perfect amount of sweetness.

by NaturalDisaster_Goddess

“Go to College.” they said.
“Get a job.” they said.
“It won’t interfere with patrols or missions.” they said.
Will was going to kill those three.

Wrote prematurely, but I’m sure that Meg and Clarence would be okay with this! So loving Snailhair for making the OC’s! XD This is the most fun writing I’ve had in a long while!

But you can thank Sammys_Rose for me posting this! I was gonna wait until Snail read it, but meh, it’s been too long so HERE YA GO FOLKS! <3

She/her if ya need to know.

blog.name: they-handed-me-the-moon
blog.title: They Handed Me The Moon
blog.description: Paige, 23, she/her, queer. This blog is for whatever catches my interest, which for now is primarily Good Omens

tags: but i'm not in the mood to spend 20 minutes making it more concise
summary: I’m honestly fascinated by Crowley’s apparent lack of any power or authority in Hell. I mean on the one hand it makes sense...
body:
I’m honestly fascinated by Crowley’s apparent lack of any power or authority in Hell. I mean on the one hand it makes sense because of course Crowley is a terrible demon with who doesn’t care twopence for Hell’s ‘cause,’ and thanks to crowleyraejepsen I tend to imagine that in Hell having power has less to do with merit than with having the right friends, for which staying on earth full-time wouldn’t exactly be conducive.

But still, this is the demon who literally caused The Fall, who from Hell’s perspective struck the first blow against God’s creation, won Hell its first foothold on earth, etc. And it’s hard to imagine Hell would just let that pass by.

So what I’m wondering is … how high are the chances that after The Fall he was invited to return to Hell and join the Inner Circle and he was just like, “nah I’m just gonna keep tempting humans up here, thx”?

Because I feel like it would explain a lot about how other demons seem to regard him. I mean obviously the Inner Circle would hate him for not wanting ‘in’ like he is supposed to, but also how would it look if they punished the demon who struck the first blow on earth? Besides, he’s proven himself valuable.

So the Inner Circle hates him, and they’re not exactly subtle about it, but they also more-or-less leave him to his devices as long as he keeps filing reports. So the other demons shun and mock him to avoid garnering mistrust by association, but there’s also this underlying thread of envy and awe, because this is the serpent, the one who was cursed by the Metatron himself and lived to tell the tale, the one who is hated by the authorities they fear and yet is left free to roam to earth as he will.

So when its time for the Apocalypse they give him The Antichrist, because there’s no denying he handled the last pivotal moment with flying colors, and they’d never admit it aloud but he does know how to navigate humanity better than the rest of them. Besides if things just happen go south and he cocks it up, well. It would be just the opportunity to take him down a peg or 2000 that demons on all levels have been looking for from nearly the beginning of time.

I’m honestly fascinated by Crowley’s apparent lack of any power or authority in Hell. I mean on the one hand it makes sense because of course Crowley is a terrible demon with who doesn’t care twopence for Hell’s ‘cause,’ and thanks to crowleyraejepsen I tend to imagine that in Hell having power has less to do with merit than with having the right friends, for which staying on earth full-time wouldn’t exactly be conducive.

But still, this is the demon who literally caused The Fall, who from Hell’s perspective struck the first blow against God’s creation, won Hell its first foothold on earth, etc. And it’s hard to imagine Hell would just let that pass by.

So what I’m wondering is … how high are the chances that after The Fall he was invited to return to Hell and join the Inner Circle and he was just like, “nah I’m just gonna keep tempting humans up here, thx”?

Because I feel like it would explain a lot about how other demons seem to regard him. I mean obviously the Inner Circle would hate him for not wanting ‘in’ like he is supposed to, but also how would it look if they punished the demon who struck the first blow on earth? Besides, he’s proven himself valuable.

So the Inner Circle hates him, and they’re not exactly subtle about it, but they also more-or-less leave him to his devices as long as he keeps filing reports. So the other demons shun and mock him to avoid garnering mistrust by association, but there’s also this underlying thread of envy and awe, because this is the serpent, the one who was cursed by the Metatron himself and lived to tell the tale, the one who is hated by the authorities they fear and yet is left free to roam to earth as he will.

So when its time for the Apocalypse they give him The Antichrist, because there’s no denying he handled the last pivotal moment with flying colors, and they’d never admit it aloud but he does know how to navigate humanity better than the rest of them. Besides if things just happen go south and he cocks it up, well. It would be just the opportunity to take him down a peg or 2000 that demons on all levels have been looking for from nearly the beginning of time.

blog.name: irisbleufic
blog.title: (lives between pages)
blog.description: Holistic Writer / INTJ / Chaotic Good / Slytherin / Jewish / QIA-spec in LGBTQIA+ / autistic rabblerouser / still in my 30s / they-pronouns. Emma Goldman stan. Survivor of traumas I only discuss when relevant. Contains black tea, insomnia, poetry, & fic—but mostly just fic. If you're looking for CoT 'Verse and the rest of my Good Omens fic, you can find it here. As of 2013, all of my old LJ-era fanfiction has been uploaded to AO3. I'm the nutter behind @ask-agnes-nutter, so feel free to send asks. I moderate for the largest, most active GO Discord server, The Ritz; if you would like an invite, please DM me. You can pester me; I strongly encourage anons, because I know not everyone finds sending asks easy. If you want to know where to find my published work, email me on irisbleufic@gmail.com or send a DM. If you make art based on my writing, podfic my stories, or do anything you want me to see, tag it #irisbleufic. I won’t tell folks they shouldn't follow, but there's complex content here. I tag thoroughly. You can ko-fi me if you wish.

summary: Final (double) update: Turn In Your Arms
title: Final (double) update: Turn In Your Arms
body:
by @irisbleufic & @procrastinatingbookworm

#7 / 8: MONDAY, 25 AUGUST 1997

#8 / 8: EPILOGUE (TUESDAY AGAIN)

[Tam Lin retelling; rated M / borderline E (NSFW).  Now complete!]

*

The gates of St. James’s Park were locked by the time they arrived, but such a barrier posed no obstacle. They cleared the bars with a thought, passing through like ghosts.

“Let there be light,” Aziraphale murmured. The walkway ahead was cast in a bluish glow.

Crowley hissed, recoiling slightly from what lay a short distance ahead. “They’re here already.”

Aziraphale took several steps forward, squinting. The bridge wasn’t quite visible, but the reddish aura emanating from the vicinity of the water was unmistakable.

“Stay behind me,” he insisted, continuing to walk. “Under no circumstances take the lead.”

With a touch of weary sarcasm, Crowley chuckled. “Get thee behind me, Satan, is that it?”

summary: I’ve talked about my Aziraphale/Crowley’s gender theory on the discord, but here it is in full. In Neilman’s other story about...
body:
I’ve talked about my Aziraphale/Crowley’s gender theory on the discord, but here it is in full.

In Neilman’s other story about angels, Murder Mysteries, Raguel explicitly tells the narrator that he, and all the other angels, don’t have any genitals. We can assume the same thing applies to the supernatural beings of Good Omens, and that’s what “sexless unless they make an effort” means. But of course, this doesn’t mean that Aziraphale and Crowley still aren’t gay on human terms (even ignoring that non-binary people often describe their attraction as gay).

What that statement does apply is that Heaven and Hell are genderless societies. With all angels being sexless and Heaven not being really big on individual identity, this seems likely. So when they first arrived on Earth, Aziraphale and Crowley probably didn’t have a concept of gender.

 And so now it’s time to bring in Discworld. First is a theme that exists mainly in Thief of TIme, where the character arcs of Death and the Horsemen are very similar to that of Aziraphale and Crowley(as in Death goes around convincing his friends to stop the Apocalypse because they love the Disc). You also see a lot of it with Unity and the Auditors. It’s that, when an immortal being spends time around humans, especially in the shape of the human, they become human-like. And we see that with Aziraphale and Crowley in the book. It’s one of the big themes, especially with how they’ve become not fully good and not fully evil (a chef’s salad in a vignette of conflict and confusion). Another element of Death’s character arc is that how one cannot study something without gaining their traits, in his case, humans. And it’s pretty clear that Aziraphale and Crowley have both studied humanity in their own way. But other than Unity giving up the name the Auditors chose from her and her pronouns going from it to her, there isn’t much of a gender thing going on when it comes to this aspect of Discworld.

So now it’s time to turn to dwarves and golems. Dwarves have an essentially genderless society, although humans read it as male and that’s how dwarves explain it to outsiders. But when Cheery started to present herself as female (and going by a non-dwarven chosen name), many dwarves did the same and created a pretty good metaphor for being trans. And of course, their concept of femininity and gender comes from humans and it’s all part of the cultural exchange between the immigrant dwarves and the humans of Ankh-Morpork. As for golems, it’s considered polite to use he (as “it” is dehumanizing and no one has told Adora about singular they, I guess) but they don’t really bother with the whole gender thing, but there is an exception. Gladys took her name and started presenting as female to satisfy Miss Maccalariat so she could clean the women’s restrooms at the post office. But to the bafflement of Moist, she seems to have picked up the concept of the gender from the other female employees of the post office. But the literalism of even freed golems does make this example a bit hard to pin down, the dwarves picking up gender from humans do still exist. Either way, the idea is the same, gender is contagious.

And so, in summary, my theory is that Aziraphale and Crowley have both picked up gender from humans (which makes them trans, I guess). Obviously, the textual evidence in the book is ambiguous, so that’s why I’ve used themes from Neilman’s and Prattchett’s other works.

summary: So on my millionth re-watch of the Good Omens trailer I noticed something super cute about the moment Aziraphale covers Crowley...
body:
So on my millionth re-watch of the Good Omens trailer I noticed something super cute about the moment Aziraphale covers Crowley with his wing. Took me a little while to realise that the shot below is a shot of Adam protecting Eve from a lion with the flaming sword.

And the shot with Aziraphale putting his wing over Crowley comes chronologically right after that shot. Aziraphale actually reaches his wing out and over Crowley taking that action at the exact same time as Adam reaches out and takes eve’s hand after killing the lion.

It almost feels like one of those subconscious moments when you reach out to someone you love even though you’re not really fully paying attention. I know they probably wont make the relationship romantic but staging this shot in such a way that these actions happen simultaneously is pretty significant. 

The mirroring of the only two people on earth with the only two angels on earth is just gorgeous.

summary: so, aziraphale, i tend to imagine as appearing in like, his mid-fifties to early sixties. @annethecatdetective earlier phrased...
body:
so, aziraphale, i tend to imagine as appearing in like, his mid-fifties to early sixties. @annethecatdetective earlier phrased it as “well-preserved” and that is exactly it, too: in his fifties/sixties, and well-preserved. 

perennially rosy-cheeked and with visibly well-moisteurized skin; watery blue eyes the colour of lakewater, which are a little bigger and rounder than they need to be, and look even more so because the lenses on his crescent-shaped spectacles are so small. round, stubby nose, also eternally quite red: rounded face with a button chin, and hair that is the sort of blond that might be described as “lank and anemic” more than “golden curls”. his eyelashes and his eyebrows, although each quite thick, look white, the colour is so pale. i kind of imagine it about six inches long at the most, and hanging around his face in a blandly curly way, like moss hanging from an affably smiling cliff face. 

and he’s plump. and i don’t mean like “he is marginally bigger than crowley, who is a beanpole”, i mean he is plump: his cheeks are full and round, he’s visibly rounded at his edges, he’s got a belly, his thighs are big, and he’s got his plump hands and his elegant manicure. i tend to imagine him at around like, 5′5″, maybe 5′6″, depending on the shoes he’s wearing. 

as for crowley, he looks to be in about his mid-to-late twenties, and looking at him, you’d maybe estimate 27, but that age is subject to a sliding scale depending on how he wants to come across. really nice skin, smooth and lightly brown with that warm undertone, and with like, a square nose, strong cheek bones, a square chin. he’s handsome, and when he smiles, his teeth are very white; lips in a natural (albeit slightly thin) cupid’s bow; very expressive eyebrows. got those sexy, sexy snake eyes, and dark brown hair that is straight and usually swept neatly back from his face. 

i don’t?? actually see him as the skinniest thing in existence, but instead like, on the thin side, with square shoulders and square hips, and generally packed with lithe muscle - not like, a six-pack, but built more like a swimmer? the muscle’s everywhere, and sort of evenly laid around. maybe 5′10″, 5′11″ - certainly taller than aziraphale (it’s a matter of principle) but not taller than everybody

tags: i see your principality!crowley and i raise you this
summary: Good Omens headcanon: Crowley is actually a Seraph, because in the Hebrew bible the term is also used to talk about snakes....
body: Good Omens headcanon: Crowley is actually a Seraph, because in the Hebrew bible the term is also used to talk about snakes. That’s also why he’s so low on Hell’s roster and why he’s the one who seems the most lucid about God’s plan through the whole book - he was one of those angels who were the closest to God before he Fell

reblog.comment: Good Omens headcanon: Crowley is actually a Seraph, because in the Hebrew bible the term is also used to talk about snakes.
